title: How to Sleep on a Chair

steps.title: Find an appropriate chair.
steps.content: Find an appropriate chair. Easy chairs and recliners offer high backs and arms to support your neck and back and allow you to settle in comfortably. Having a chair with enough room to switch positions or shift your body during the night will also help you sleep better.

steps.title: Elevate your feet.
steps.content: Elevate your feet. Use an ottoman, stool, chair, or coffee table to keep your feet off the floor. Put a pillow under your feet for extra support. Keeping your legs elevated helps prevent leg cramps and poor circulation. If you are unable to elevate your legs, wear compression socks to prevent blood clots. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Collect bedding.
steps.content: Collect bedding. Gather blankets to keep you warm during the night, a time when your body temperature naturally drops. [2] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Larger blankets that cover your entire body will help keep you warm. Find pillows that can support your neck, back, and legs. U-shaped travel neck pillows are a comfortable option for supporting your neck. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Make the room dark and quiet.
steps.content: Make the room dark and quiet. Close the curtains and turn out the lights. Turn off televisions, computers, tablets, or phones. By creating a "nighttime" atmosphere, your body will feel like it needs to sleep. [4] X Expert Source Alex Dimitriu, MD Sleep Specialist Expert Interview. 16 October 2019. Closed drapes help you sleep later in the day by preventing the sun from shining through the windows and waking you up early. The light from electronic screens sends signals to your brain that it should be awake. It is best to reduce use of these products before bedtime. Shutting down your phone completely or turning off its visual and sonic notifications decreases potential light and sound interruptions. Be sure to have a back-up alarm clock if you turn off your phone completely. Use ear plugs to negate street noise and/or an eye mask to enhance the room's darkness.

steps.title: Change into loose-fitting clothing.
steps.content: Change into loose-fitting clothing. Pajamas are a great option. If you do not have pajamas or another change of clothes with you, make yourself more comfortable by removing items such as belts, ties, or pantyhose. Take off your shoes, jewelry, and remove eyeglasses

steps.title: Drink a cup of herbal tea or warm milk.
steps.content: Drink a cup of herbal tea or warm milk. A warm drink before bed will help you relax. Warm drinks also help prevent going to bed dehydrated. Having a glass or bottle of water near your chair will help with hydration through the night. Dairy products contain ample amounts of amino acid tryptophan, which induces pro-sleep brain chemicals serotonin and melatonin. [5] X Research source Camomile, passion flower tea, and valerian teas have sedative effects. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Complete your nighttime hygiene routine.
steps.content: Complete your nighttime hygiene routine. Brush your teeth and floss. Wash your face or if possible, take a shower or hot bath. Preparing for bed with your usual ritual will help you unwind and prepare to sleep. When you soak in warm water, your temperature rises. The cool down period following a bath or shower relaxes you.

steps.title: Cover yourself with a large blanket.
steps.content: Cover yourself with a large blanket. Depending on the temperature of the room, choose a blanket that keeps you at a comfortable temperature. Consider having a few options for blankets in case the temperature fluctuates. Tuck the blanket over your shoulders, around your body, and under your legs and feet to prevent drafts.

steps.title: Support your head with your pillow.
steps.content: Support your head with your pillow. Choose a pillow that will stay in place and provide support for your neck. If a pillow is unavailable, consider using a rolled-up sweatshirt or towel. Aim for both comfort and support in choosing pillows.

steps.title: Try the 4-7-8 breathing technique.
steps.content: Try the 4-7-8 breathing technique. Controlled breathing allows you to focus on the moment and clear your head. The extra oxygen acts as a "natural tranquilizer for the nervous system." This breathing exercise can lull you to sleep. Exhale completely through your mouth while making a "whoosh'" sound. Close your mouth and inhale through your nose to the count of four. Hold your breath to the count of seven. Exhale completely through your mouth with the "whoosh" sound for eight seconds Inhale again and repeat the cycle three times. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Stay relaxed.
steps.content: Stay relaxed. If you cannot fall asleep immediately, do not become anxious. Continue slow, controlled breathing and try to keep your eyes closed. Focus on relaxing each muscle and resting your body and mind. If you still can't fall asleep after 20 minutes, get up and do a relaxing activity, like reading a book, and then try again. [8] X Expert Source Alex Dimitriu, MD Sleep Specialist Expert Interview. 16 October 2019.
